comment_text.mn100:2.2: A brahmin lady of the same name also trips and utters praise of the Buddha in SN 7.1. Nonetheless, most other details of the stories are different, including the location and the subsequent teaching. There, her husband gets angry, goes to confront by the Buddha, but is converted by his teaching on the harm of anger. The historical relation between these two texts is unclear. Regardless, they do attest to the use of Buddhist invocations from an early date. A similar invocation is expressed for the Great Steward at DN 19:58.5.
comment_text.mn100:3.1: A “brahmin” Saṅgārava of Sāvatthī appears in a number of discourses, and his spiritual progression can be traced. He practiced purification in water (SN 7.21) and (apparently later) asked the Buddha about sacrifice (AN 3.60). He further asked how hymns are remembered (SN 46.55, AN 5.193). In all these discourses he was said to have gone for refuge at the end, as does the Saṅgārava of the current discourse. Finally he asks the more meaningful spiritual question about the near shore and far shore (AN 10.117, AN 10.169). It is possible that the teenage “student” (māṇava) Saṅgārava living at Caṇḍalakappa graduated and moved to nearby Sāvatthī where he became known as the “brahmin” Saṅgārava. This would only make sense, however, if we disregard the statements on going for refuge, as he clearly followed the Brahmanical path for quite some time.
comment_text.mn100:3.4: The relationship between Saṅgārava and Dhanañjānī is not specified in the text, but she was probably the wife of his brahmin teacher.
comment_text.mn100:5.5: Text drops a -ti, apparently by mistake; evaṁ bhoti should be evaṁ bhotīti.
comment_text.mn100:6.1: For the phrase “having attained perfection and consummation of insight”, see MN 77:15.6.
comment_text.mn100:7.6: Elsewhere, reason and faith are regarded as two distinct means of knowledge (eg. MN 95:14.5), and their conflation here is probably a redaction error. In the Sanskrit parallel, faith applies to all the means of knowledge, in the sense that they have faith in those means. (Lixiang Zhang, Das Śaṁkarasūtra, 2004, cited in Anālayo, Comparative Study volume 2.)
comment_text.mn100:42.1: This final passage has been widely misunderstood. K.R. Norman (“The Buddha’s View of Devas”) argued that the passage is corrupt, and Bodhi, while not endorsing Norman’s emendations, agrees. However, while there are difficulties in readings and interpretations, for the most part the Pali makes good sense. The opening showed Saṅgārava being overreactive and dogmatic, an impression reinforced here by his sudden changes of topic and misunderstandings. Note too that the Saṅgārava of AN 3.60 is evasive and a little rude, reminiscent of the prickly and unpredictable personality on display in the current sutta. I think the bulk of the difficulties simply represent a lively but somewhat chaotic exchange, although textual corruption cannot be ruled out. However, note that Sanskrit fragments indicate that in that version this discussion happened before the bulk of the sutta teachings. I agree with Anālayo that the Sanskrit form makes better sense (Comparative Study, volume ii, page 583).
comment_text.mn100:42.2: Read aṭṭhita as ā+ṭhita, “assiduous”; see Ja 242:2.1 in the same sense, and compare Sanskrit āsthita. | I follow the variant vata rather than vataṁ, as exclamations with repeated vata are idiomatic.
comment_text.mn100:42.4: The sense of atthi devā is established from such passages as MN 90:13.2.
comment_text.mn100:42.5: Ṭhānaso here means “in terms of cause” or “by way of cause”. It typically appears in the context of kamma and rebirth, followed by a verb of knowing, eg. ṭhānaso hetuso vipākaṁ yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, “understands results (of kamma) in terms of grounds and causes” (MN 12:11.2). The Buddha’s point is that the survival of gods is not a metaphysical absolute but depends on their kamma. | As usual, the Buddha answers such questions framed with atthi indirectly; see note on MN 90:13.2. | That adhideva means “about the gods” is established at MN 90:17.8.
comment_text.mn100:42.8: Normally such a phrase would include a reference to the Buddha’s speech (as eg. MN 80:3.15). But this is lacking in the Pali so I omit it.
comment_text.mn100:42.11: This should be read in light of SN 12.15:2.2, where “survival” or “existence” (atthita) is understood by seeing “origin” (samudaya), while non-existence is understood by seeing “cessation”. Here too the survival of gods is understood in terms of cause.
comment_text.mn100:42.12: The Buddha’s answer relied on the implication that since gods depend on causes they “survive” in the sense of being reborn, but not in the sense of eternal existence. Saṅgārava didn’t follow the argument.
comment_text.mn100:42.13: I think the Buddha felt that since it is agreed “by the eminent” (uccena)—which would include the brahmanical teachers of Saṅgārava—that gods are real, this could be assumed. So the Buddha’s response was aimed at clarifying the kind of existence that gods have, namely, a conditioned and impermanent existence determined by the kamma. When faced with the same question at MN 90:13.2, the Buddha’s immediate response was to ask for a clarification, so the confusion did not arise.

root_text.mn100:3.2: Assosi kho saṅgāravo māṇavo dhanañjāniyā brāhmaṇiyā evaṁ vācaṁ bhāsamānāya.

root_text.mn100:5.3: “ayaṁ, tāta bhadramukha, so bhagavā cañcalikappaṁ anuppatto, cañcalikappe viharati todeyyānaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ ambavane.

root_text.mn100:14.11: “Evameva kho, bhāradvāja, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi avūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
root_text.mn100:14.12: Ayaṁ kho maṁ, bhāradvāja, paṭhamā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn100:15.1: Aparāpi kho maṁ, bhāradvāja, dutiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn100:15.2: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ.
root_text.mn100:15.6: api nu so puriso amuṁ allaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ sasnehaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya tejo pātukareyyā”ti?

root_text.mn100:15.10: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti. “Evameva kho, bhāradvāja, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ na suppahīno hoti na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. root_text.mn100:16.2: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, sukkhaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ koḷāpaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ.
root_text.mn100:16.6: api nu so puriso amuṁ sukkhaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ koḷāpaṁ ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṁ uttarāraṇiṁ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṁ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn100:16.9: Aduñhi, bho gotama, sukkhaṁ kaṭṭhaṁ koḷāpaṁ, tañca pana ārakā udakā thale nikkhittan”ti.
root_text.mn100:16.10: “Evameva kho, bhāradvāja, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṁ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṁ suppahīno hoti suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, bhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. root_text.mn100:16.11: Ayaṁ kho maṁ, bhāradvāja, tatiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn100:16.12: Imā kho maṁ, bhāradvāja, tisso upamā paṭibhaṁsu anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
root_text.mn100:17.2: ‘yannūnāhaṁ dantebhidantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇheyyaṁ abhinippīḷeyyaṁ abhisantāpeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn100:17.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, dantebhidantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhāmi abhinippīḷemi abhisantāpemi.
root_text.mn100:17.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, dantebhidantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
root_text.mn100:17.5: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, balavā puriso dubbalataraṁ purisaṁ sīse vā gahetvā khandhe vā gahetvā abhiniggaṇheyya abhinippīḷeyya abhisantāpeyya;
root_text.mn100:17.6: evameva kho me, bhāradvāja, dantebhidantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṁ āhacca, cetasā cittaṁ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
root_text.mn100:17.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:18.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn100:18.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṁ nikkhamantānaṁ adhimatto saddo hoti.
root_text.mn100:18.5: Seyyathāpi nāma kammāragaggariyā dhamamānāya adhimatto saddo hoti;
root_text.mn100:18.6: evameva kho me, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṁ nikkhamantānaṁ adhimatto saddo hoti.
root_text.mn100:18.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:19.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn100:19.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
root_text.mn100:19.5: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, balavā puriso, tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya;
root_text.mn100:19.6: evameva kho me, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
root_text.mn100:19.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:20.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn100:20.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.
root_text.mn100:20.5: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena sīse sīsaveṭhaṁ dadeyya;
root_text.mn100:20.6: evameva kho, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.
root_text.mn100:20.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:21.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn100:21.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā kucchiṁ parikantanti.
root_text.mn100:21.5: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā tiṇhena govikantanena kucchiṁ parikanteyya;
root_text.mn100:21.6: evameva kho me, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā kucchiṁ parikantanti.
root_text.mn100:21.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā; sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:22.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṁ.
root_text.mn100:22.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimatto kāyasmiṁ ḍāho hoti.
root_text.mn100:22.5: Seyyathāpi, bhāradvāja, dve balavanto purisā dubbalataraṁ purisaṁ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuyā santāpeyyuṁ samparitāpeyyuṁ;
root_text.mn100:22.6: evameva kho me, bhāradvāja, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimatto kāyasmiṁ ḍāho hoti.
root_text.mn100:22.7: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhāradvāja, vīriyaṁ hoti asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho, teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
root_text.mn100:23.1: Apissu maṁ, bhāradvāja, devatā disvā evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.mn100:23.4: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, api ca kālaṁ karotī’ti.
root_text.mn100:23.6: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, nāpi kālaṁ karoti;
root_text.mn100:23.7: arahaṁ samaṇo gotamo, vihāro tveva so arahato evarūpo hotī’ti.
root_text.mn100:24.3: Atha kho maṁ, bhāradvāja, devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn100:24.4: ‘mā kho tvaṁ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajji.
root_text.mn100:24.5: Sace kho tvaṁ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajjissasi, tassa te mayaṁ dibbaṁ ojaṁ lomakūpehi ajjhohāressāma.
root_text.mn100:24.8: ‘ahañceva kho pana sabbaso ajajjitaṁ paṭijāneyyaṁ, imā ca me devatā dibbaṁ ojaṁ lomakūpehi ajjhohāreyyuṁ, tāya cāhaṁ yāpeyyaṁ.
root_text.mn100:24.10: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, tā devatā paccācikkhāmi, ‘halan’ti vadāmi.
root_text.mn100:25.2: ‘yannūnāhaṁ thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhāreyyaṁ pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsan’ti.
root_text.mn100:25.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṁ.
root_text.mn100:25.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, thokaṁ thokaṁ āhāraṁ āhārayato pasataṁ pasataṁ, yadi vā muggayūsaṁ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṁ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṁ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṁ, adhimattakasimānaṁ patto kāyo hoti.
root_text.mn100:25.5: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.6: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṁ; evamevassu me ānisadaṁ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya;
root_text.mn100:25.7: seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako uṇṇatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.8: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.9: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.10: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.11: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, ‘udaracchaviṁ parimasissāmī’ti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi, ‘piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ parimasissāmī’ti udaracchaviṁyeva pariggaṇhāmi; yāvassu me, bhāradvāja, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṁ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.12: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, ‘vaccaṁ vā muttaṁ vā karissāmī’ti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:25.13: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, imameva kāyaṁ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anumajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, pāṇinā gattāni anumajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā papatanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:26.1: Apissu maṁ, bhāradvāja, manussā disvā evamāhaṁsu: ‘kāḷo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
root_text.mn100:26.2: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṁsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo, sāmo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
root_text.mn100:26.3: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṁsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo napi sāmo, maṅguracchavi samaṇo gotamo’ti;
root_text.mn100:26.4: yāvassu me, bhāradvāja, tāva parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto upahato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
root_text.mn100:27.2: ‘ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayiṁsu, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo;
root_text.mn100:27.3: yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṁ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayissanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo;
root_text.mn100:27.4: yepi hi keci etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, etāvaparamaṁ, nayito bhiyyo.
root_text.mn100:27.5: Na kho panāhaṁ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya adhigacchāmi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṁ.
root_text.mn100:27.6: Siyā nu kho añño maggo bodhāyā’ti?
root_text.mn100:28.2: ‘abhijānāmi kho panāhaṁ pitu sakkassa kammante sītāya jambucchāyāya nisinno vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharitā.
root_text.mn100:28.3: Siyā nu kho eso maggo bodhāyā’ti?
root_text.mn100:28.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhāradvāja, satānusāri viññāṇaṁ ahosi:
root_text.mn100:29.2: ‘kiṁ nu kho ahaṁ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi yaṁ taṁ sukhaṁ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti?
root_text.mn100:29.4: ‘na kho ahaṁ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi yaṁ taṁ sukhaṁ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
root_text.mn100:30.2: ‘na kho taṁ sukaraṁ sukhaṁ adhigantuṁ evaṁ adhimattakasimānaṁ pattakāyena.
root_text.mn100:30.4: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ odanakummāsaṁ.
root_text.mn100:30.5: Tena kho pana maṁ, bhāradvāja, samayena pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū paccupaṭṭhitā honti:
root_text.mn100:30.6: ‘yaṁ kho samaṇo gotamo dhammaṁ adhigamissati taṁ no ārocessatī’ti.
root_text.mn100:30.7: Yato kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāresiṁ odanakummāsaṁ, atha me te pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū nibbijja pakkamiṁsu:
root_text.mn100:31-33.1: So kho ahaṁ, bhāradvāja, oḷārikaṁ āhāraṁ āhāretvā balaṁ gahetvā vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn100:31-33.2: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
root_text.mn100:34.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn100:34.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi.
root_text.mn100:35.1: Ayaṁ kho me, bhāradvāja, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā,
root_text.mn100:35.2: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn100:36-38.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn100:36-38.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi …pe…
root_text.mn100:36-38.3: ayaṁ kho me, bhāradvāja, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā
root_text.mn100:36-38.4: vijjā adhigatā, avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn100:39.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn100:39.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ;
root_text.mn100:39.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn100:40.1: Tassa me evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha.
root_text.mn100:40.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn100:41.1: Ayaṁ kho me, bhāradvāja, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā
root_text.mn100:41.2: vijjā adhigatā, avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato”ti.
root_text.mn100:42.1: Evaṁ vutte, saṅgāravo māṇavo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn100:42.2: “aṭṭhitavataṁ bhoto gotamassa padhānaṁ ahosi, sappurisavataṁ bhoto gotamassa padhānaṁ ahosi;
root_text.mn100:42.4: Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, atthi devā”ti?
root_text.mn100:42.7: “Kiṁ nu kho, bho gotama, ‘atthi devā’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘ṭhānaso metaṁ, bhāradvāja, viditaṁ yadidaṁ adhidevā’ti vadesi.
root_text.mn100:42.8: Nanu, bho gotama, evaṁ sante tucchā musā hotī”ti?
root_text.mn100:42.9: “‘Atthi devā’ti, bhāradvāja, puṭṭho samāno ‘atthi devā’ti yo vadeyya, ‘ṭhānaso me viditā’ti yo vadeyya;
root_text.mn100:42.10: atha khvettha viññunā purisena ekaṁsena niṭṭhaṁ gantabbaṁ yadidaṁ:
root_text.mn100:42.12: “Kissa pana me bhavaṁ gotamo ādikeneva na byākāsī”ti?
root_text.mn100:42.13: “Uccena sammataṁ kho etaṁ, bhāradvāja, lokasmiṁ yadidaṁ:

root_text.mn100:43.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.mn100:43.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.mn100:43.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.mn100:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn100:2.1: Now at that time a brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī was residing at Caṇḍalakappa. She was devoted to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn100:2.2: Once, she tripped and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
translation_text.mn100:2.3: “Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn100:2.4: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
translation_text.mn100:2.5: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
translation_text.mn100:3.1: Now at that time the student Saṅgārava was residing in Caṇḍalakappa. He was young, newly tonsured; he was sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
translation_text.mn100:3.4: “The brahmin lady Dhanañjānī is a disgrace! Though brahmins proficient in the three Vedas are found, she praises that shaveling, that fake ascetic.”
translation_text.mn100:3.5: “But dearest boy, you don’t understand the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.
translation_text.mn100:3.6: If you did, you’d never think of abusing or insulting him.”
translation_text.mn100:3.7: “Well then, ma’am, let me know when the Buddha arrives in Caṇḍalakappa.”
translation_text.mn100:4.1: And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Kosalan lands, arrived at Caṇḍalakappa,
translation_text.mn100:4.2: where he stayed in the mango grove of the Todeyya brahmins.
translation_text.mn100:5.1: Dhanañjānī heard that he had arrived.
translation_text.mn100:5.2: So she went to Saṅgārava and told him, adding,
translation_text.mn100:5.4: “Please, dearest boy, go at your convenience.”
translation_text.mn100:5.5: “Yes, ma’am,” replied Saṅgārava. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn100:5.6: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn100:6.1: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in this life.
translation_text.mn100:6.2: Where do you stand regarding these?”
translation_text.mn100:7.1: “I say there is a disparity among those who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in this life.
translation_text.mn100:7.2: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are oral transmitters.
translation_text.mn100:7.3: Through oral transmission they claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn100:7.4: For example, the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas.
translation_text.mn100:7.5: There are some ascetics and brahmins who solely by mere faith claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn100:7.6: For example, those who rely on logic and inquiry.
translation_text.mn100:7.7: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, having directly known for themselves the principle regarding teachings not learned before from another, claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn100:8.1: And here’s a way to understand that I am one of them.
translation_text.mn100:9.1: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
translation_text.mn100:9.2: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
translation_text.mn100:9.3: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn100:9.4: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn100:9.5: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn100:9.6: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
translation_text.mn100:9.7: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
translation_text.mn100:9.10: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
translation_text.mn100:9.12: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
translation_text.mn100:9.14: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
translation_text.mn100:9.15: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
translation_text.mn100:10.1: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him:
translation_text.mn100:10.2: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’
translation_text.mn100:10.3: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
translation_text.mn100:10.5: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
translation_text.mn100:10.9: and wisdom; I too have these things.
translation_text.mn100:10.10: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’
translation_text.mn100:10.11: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
translation_text.mn100:10.12: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
translation_text.mn100:10.13: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
translation_text.mn100:10.15: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
translation_text.mn100:10.16: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
translation_text.mn100:10.17: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
translation_text.mn100:10.18: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.
translation_text.mn100:10.19: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.
translation_text.mn100:10.20: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.
translation_text.mn100:10.21: I am like you and you are like me.
translation_text.mn100:10.22: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
translation_text.mn100:10.23: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with high praise.
translation_text.mn100:10.25: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
translation_text.mn100:10.26: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

translation_text.mn100:13.1: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.
translation_text.mn100:13.2: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn100:13.4: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.
translation_text.mn100:13.5: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’
translation_text.mn100:13.6: So I sat down right there, thinking:
translation_text.mn100:14.1: And then these three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:14.2: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.
translation_text.mn100:14.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn100:14.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn100:14.6: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn100:14.9: Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.
translation_text.mn100:14.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn100:14.11: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn100:14.12: This was the first example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:15.1: Then a second example occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:15.2: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.
translation_text.mn100:15.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn100:15.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn100:15.6: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn100:15.9: Because it’s still a green, sappy log, despite the fact that it’s lying on dry land far from water.
translation_text.mn100:15.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.” “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. But they haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn100:15.11: This was the second example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:16.1: Then a third example occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:16.2: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.
translation_text.mn100:16.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
translation_text.mn100:16.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
translation_text.mn100:16.6: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
translation_text.mn100:16.9: Because it’s a dried up, withered log, and it’s lying on dry land far from water.”
translation_text.mn100:16.10: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. And they have internally given up and stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are capable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
translation_text.mn100:16.11: This was the third example that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:16.12: These are the three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, that occurred to me.
translation_text.mn100:17.2: ‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and scorch mind with mind?’
translation_text.mn100:17.4: until sweat ran from my armpits.
translation_text.mn100:17.5: It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and crushes them.
translation_text.mn100:17.6: In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and crushed mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits.
translation_text.mn100:17.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn100:18.2: ‘Why don’t I practice the breathless absorption?’
translation_text.mn100:18.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
translation_text.mn100:18.4: But then winds came out my ears making a severe noise,
translation_text.mn100:18.5: like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.
translation_text.mn100:18.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

translation_text.mn100:19.4: But then severe winds ground my head,
translation_text.mn100:19.5: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.
translation_text.mn100:19.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

translation_text.mn100:20.4: But then I got a severe headache,

translation_text.mn100:20.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

translation_text.mn100:21.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

translation_text.mn100:22.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
translation_text.mn100:23.1: Then some deities saw me and said,
translation_text.mn100:23.6: ‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’
translation_text.mn100:24.2: ‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’
translation_text.mn100:24.3: But deities came to me and said,
translation_text.mn100:24.4: ‘Good fellow, don’t practice totally cutting off food.
translation_text.mn100:24.5: If you do, we’ll infuse heavenly nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’
translation_text.mn100:24.8: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing heavenly nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’
translation_text.mn100:24.10: So I refused those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’
translation_text.mn100:25.2: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a handful of broth made from mung beans, horse gram, chickpeas, or green gram?’
translation_text.mn100:25.4: until my body became severely emaciated.
translation_text.mn100:25.5: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
translation_text.mn100:25.6: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
translation_text.mn100:25.7: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
translation_text.mn100:25.8: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
translation_text.mn100:25.9: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
translation_text.mn100:25.10: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
translation_text.mn100:25.11: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
translation_text.mn100:25.12: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
translation_text.mn100:25.13: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
translation_text.mn100:26.1: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’
translation_text.mn100:26.2: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’
translation_text.mn100:26.3: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has dingy skin.’
translation_text.mn100:26.4: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.
translation_text.mn100:27.2: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.
translation_text.mn100:27.5: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.
translation_text.mn100:27.6: Could there be another path to awakening?’
translation_text.mn100:28.2: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of a black plum tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn100:28.3: Could that be the path to awakening?’
translation_text.mn100:28.4: Stemming from that memory came the understanding:
translation_text.mn100:29.2: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’
translation_text.mn100:29.4: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’
translation_text.mn100:30.2: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so severely emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’
translation_text.mn100:30.4: So I ate some solid food.
translation_text.mn100:30.5: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,
translation_text.mn100:30.6: ‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’
translation_text.mn100:30.7: But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying,
translation_text.mn100:30.8: ‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’
translation_text.mn100:31-33.1: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption …
translation_text.mn100:31-33.2: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn100:34.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn100:34.2: I recollected many past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn100:35.1: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
translation_text.mn100:35.2: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn100:36-38.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn100:36-38.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds …
translation_text.mn100:36-38.3: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
translation_text.mn100:36-38.4: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn100:39.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn100:39.2: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn100:39.3: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn100:40.1: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn100:40.2: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
translation_text.mn100:40.3: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn100:41.1: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
translation_text.mn100:41.2: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.”
translation_text.mn100:42.1: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn100:42.2: “The striving of the worthy Gotama was indeed assiduous and that of a true person,
translation_text.mn100:42.3: since he is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn100:42.4: But worthy Gotama, do gods survive?”
translation_text.mn100:42.5: “I’ve understood about gods in terms of causes.”
translation_text.mn100:42.7: “But worthy Gotama, when asked ‘Do gods survive?’ why did you say that you have understood about gods in terms of causes?
translation_text.mn100:42.8: That being so, is it not hollow and false?”
translation_text.mn100:42.9: “When asked ‘Do gods survive’, whether you reply ‘Gods survive’ or ‘I’ve understood in terms of causes’
translation_text.mn100:42.10: a sensible person would come to the categorical conclusion in this matter that
translation_text.mn100:42.12: “But why didn’t you say that in the first place?”
translation_text.mn100:42.13: “It is agreed by the eminent in the world that gods survive.”
translation_text.mn100:43.1: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn100:43.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.mn100:43.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn100:43.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
